title: Fix instance detection for inliner optimization
body:
Caused by #648.  I'll try to review for similar breakages.  I already caught the MagicDo one in the original PR, so should've thought of this one.

I do note that this `isOpDict` check is different than the `isEffDict` check in that it doesn't optimize within `Prelude`.  I guess that doesn't matter.

title: 0.5.7 regression: simple numeric code no longer gets optimized to simple JavaScript

milestone.description: The goal is to reimplement `psc` in PureScript.

body:
```
% psc --version
0.5.7
% cat src/Chapter2.purs 
module Chapter2 where
import Debug.Trace
main = print (1 + 2 * 3)
% psc src/Chapter2.purs| grep "var main"
    var main = Debug_Trace.print(Prelude.showNumber)(Prelude["+"](Prelude.numNumber)(1)(Prelude["*"](Prelude.numNumber)(2)(3)));
```

according to @dylex on IRC, "isOpDict in Optimizer.Inliner needs fixing"

title: fix link to release doc
body: My first humble contribution :smile:

title: Fix #634
body:
At this point, I can't remember why I didn't want to use this syntax for the empty row. If anyone remembers, please let me know. Otherwise, `test-everything` passes, so I reckon this is fine.

@garyb @joneshf Comments? Could you review please?

title: Tweak error message for nullary top level cases
body: Resolves #649

title: Simultaneously substitute type variables
body:
This one falls into the category of "it's amazing it hasn't broken already". Also, it turns out `lens` is a great source of type-class related test cases :)

The fix is to substitute all type vars simultaneously, since the substitutions may not commute.

Resolves #652. Tested with `test-everything`.

title: Bug in replaceAllTypeVars

milestone.description: The goal is to reimplement `psc` in PureScript.

body:
From @joneshf 

```
module Instance where
 
  class Foo a b
 
  class Bar a c
 
  class (Foo a b, Bar a c) <= Baz a b c
 
  instance foo :: Foo (a -> b) a
 
  instance bar :: Bar (a -> b) b
 
  instance baz :: (Eq a) => Baz (a -> b) a b
```

gives

```
Error at instance.purs line 13, column 3: 
Error in declaration baz
No instance found for Instance.Bar (a691 -> a691) b69
```

title: Fix #618
body: @garyb @joneshf I think this is good to go, other than adding a few more tests. Could you please review?

title: Poor error message for duplicate top level value declarations

milestone.description: The goal is to reimplement `psc` in PureScript.

body:
``` haskell
module Test where
  foo = true
  foo = true
```
```
Error at test.purs line 3, column 1:
Error in module Test
Top level case disallowed in declaration foo
```

title: Define type instances without wrapper function
body:
All test cases are passing, and test-everything is no more broken than without, but this probably isn't ready yet. Certain types of recursive definitions between instances may not work, but I haven't yet thought of any that weren't already broken by #365.

This required sorting binding groups by their immediate dependencies (those not wrapped in function bodies).  This is not perfect, as those functions may be evaluated immediately, but in any generated instance declarations they are not.

title: Create .tar.gz bundle during Travis build
body: @garyb @joneshf I made this to bundle up the Mac distribution, but it also works nicely during the Travis build. @garyb, if you have Cygwin, maybe we could even tweak the script to generate Windows executables?

title: Fix #457
body: This fixes the case in the bug report, but doesn't fix the related case where `hasX` has a type with an open row. I'll work on that next.

title: Fix #457
body:
I think this fixes #457 but I want to make sure it definitely hasn't broken anything before merging.

Also, I'm not sure this is a general fix for the issue - it might just magically work in this case.

title: Check exports
body: Closing #562 again, and also checks that when a class is exported so are all its members, as suggested by @jdegoes.

title: Remove --runtime-type-checks

body:
It's broken anyway in light of the new `__unused` changes (not complaining, I've wanted to remove this for a while, this is just my excuse).

The preferred approach should be to use `Data.Foreign`.

title: Empty Row Inferred

milestone.description: The goal is to reimplement `psc` in PureScript.

body:
```haskell
foreign import type Foo :: # * -> *

foreign import foo :: forall r. { | r } -> Foo r

test = foo {}
```

Externs file will contain a type with an (invalid) empty row.

title: Unknow value arbitary
body:
I am using the starte-kit after npm install and bower update, compiling it give me this error:

Warning: Error at bower_components/purescript-lists/src/Control/Monad/ListT.purs line 106, column 17:
Error in module Control.Monad.ListT
Unknown value 'arbitrary' Use --force to continue.

title: Better overlapping instances check
body:
@garyb @jdegoes @joneshf  Mind reviewing this?

This is asymptotically slower than the old check, but I think it is more robust, and easier to understand.

title: Type of Ref not inferred

milestone.description: The goal is to reimplement `psc` in PureScript.

body:
From @cschneid

Marking this to take a look later. This code doesn't work when either of the two `trace` lines are uncommented. In the first case, it fails to unify Number and String (correct). In the second case, it complains about a lack of `Show` instance (seemingly incorrect)

```
module Main where
 
import Debug.Trace
import React
import React.DOM
import Control.Monad.Eff
import Control.Monad.Eff.Ref
 
clickTitle appState x = do
  old <- readRef appState
  let new = old + 1
  writeRef appState new
  trace $ "Value is: " ++ show new
  return Unit
 
topBar appState = mkUI spec do
  props <- getProps
  return $ h1 [ className "title"
              , onClick (clickTitle appState)
              , style { background: "#118811" }
              ] [
                text props.title
              ]
 
readAppState a = readRef a
 
counter appState = mkUI spec do
  ref <- readRef appState
  {-- trace $ ref --}
  {-- trace $ show ref --}
  return $ p [
              className "Counter"
            ] [
              text " Click me to increment!"
            ]
 
main = do
  state <- newRef 0
  let topComponent     = topBar state { title: "React for Angelo" }
  let counterComponent = counter state {}
 
  let wrapper = div' [ topComponent, counterComponent ]
  renderToBody wrapper
```

title: Is there any equivalent to 'on' in purescript?
Chapter2 examples from book not compiling: "unknown module 'Math'"
body:
Here's the file I've constructed:

```
module Chapter2 where

import Math
import Debug.Trace

diagonal w h = sqrt (w * w + h * h)

main = print (diagonal 3 4)
```

When compiling using grunt or `psc src/Chapter2.purs --output dist/Main.js --main Chapter2 --module Chapter2`, I get this error:

```
Error at src/Chapter2.purs line 3, column 1:
Error in module Chapter2
Cannot import unknown module 'Math'
```

Where am I going wrong?

title: Fix grammar and stray type var in types doc
body: The only questionable thing here is removing the type variable from the datatype Foo example.  It's never mentioned, so it seems more confusing with it, but perhaps it was meant to demonstrate that datatype can have type variables?
